selected_quotes: Olympic provides significant advantage over Power Lifting in Vertical Jump Performance changes in Football Players
It's no use being strong if you don't have the time to generate the force
OL squats superior to low bar for sports performance

citation.abstract: Twenty members of an National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III collegiate football team were assigned to either an Olympic lifting (OL) group or power lifting (PL) group. Each group was matched by position and trained 4-days.wk(-1) for 15 weeks. Testing consisted of field tests to evaluate strength (1RM squat and bench press), 40-yard sprint, agility, vertical jump height (VJ), and vertical jump power (VJP). No significant pre- to posttraining differences were observed in 1RM bench press, 40-yard sprint, agility, VJ or in VJP in either group. Significant improvements were seen in 1RM squat in both the OL and PL groups. After log10-transformation, OL were observed to have a significantly greater improvement in Delta VJ than PL. Despite an 18% greater improvement in 1RM squat (p > 0.05), and a twofold greater improvement (p > 0.05) in 40-yard sprint time by OL, no further significant group differences were seen. Results suggest that OL can provide a significant advantage over PL in vertical jump performance changes.
citation.title: Comparison of Olympic vs. traditional power lifting training programs in football players.

author.name: Jason Cholewa

facebook.summary:
That was a really cool study to read on this Sunday fun day afternoon. 

Results: Powerlifters gained absolute strength, weightlifters increased in ballistic measures (40 yrd dash & vertical jump). 

No shocker there. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov
